body:
This resource is designed to assist you with your video assessment. 


Ulster University has a dedicated video platform for lecturer and student created content.
title: Text Title

body:
Here you will learn about this platform and how to use it in order to create, upload and submit videos.


You should familiarise yourself with this content before starting your assessment, then refer to it as and when you need.
title: intro

displayTitle: There are 3 STEPS to a Video Submission. Can you order them correctly?
title: 3 steps

_feedback.correct:
Well Done! You are right. Here is a little more information on each step.


The first step is indeed recording your video, although you will want to plan beforehand of course.


The second step is uploading your video to Panopto. If you are using the Panopto app, this will be done automatically for you. At this stage you can also edit your video.


Finally, you must submit your video to the Blackboard Assignment. It's really important to follow the exact steps described in this guide.

_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite, try again and see if you can get it right.
_incorrect.final:
Not quite, but that's ok. Here are the steps in the correct order:


1. Record

The first step is indeed recording your video, although you will want to plan beforehand of course.


2.Upload

The second step is uploading your video to Panopto. If you are using the Panopto app, this will be done automatically for you. At this stage you can also edit your video.


3.Submit

Finally, you must submit your video to the Blackboard Assignment. It's really important to follow the exact steps described in this guide.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Almost, try again to see if you can get it right.
_partlyCorrect.final:
Not quite, but that's ok. Here are the steps in the correct order:


1. Record

The first step is indeed recording your video, although you will want to plan beforehand of course.


2.Upload

The second step is uploading your video to Panopto. If you are using the Panopto app, this will be done automatically for you. At this stage you can also edit your video.


3.Submit

Finally, you must submit your video to the Blackboard Assignment. It's really important to follow the exact steps described in this guide.

_items.text: Record
Upload
Submit

cancelButtonAriaLabel: This button cancels the current selected option
title: Ordering Title

body: There are 3 main steps you need to follow in order to submit a video assignment.
title: Text Title

_items.title: Step 1
_items.body:
Record your video.


There are two main ways to record your video:

  1. Record the video with your phone or camera
  2. Record it with a computer.


Your choice should be guided by the type of content you need to record.

Upload your video to your Panopto Account


Whether you have used a mobile device or a computer, you need to upload your video to your Panopto account. At this point, you can choose to edit your video or proceed to the next step.
_items.title: Step 2
Step 3
_items.body: Now that your video is on your Panopto personal area, you need to submit to the Blackboard assignment.

body: You may be asked to create a specific type of video which will require a different approach and tools.
title: Text Title

_items.title: Screen recording / screencast
_items.body:
You have been asked to record your voice over a software demonstration, or anything else that is displayed on a computer screen.


You could use the Panopto app on a computer.

_items.title: Presentation
_items.body:
You have been asked to film yourself presenting, you may be using presentation aids such as a PowerPoint presentation. 


In this case, you can use a computer, a (web)camera and the Panopto app.



You could also record yourself using a mobile phone or tablet. 


In this case, you can add Powerpoint slides at a later point in the Panopto video editor (online).

Maybe you have been asked to interview people, investigate a topic, use many different sources such as videos, pictures, music or software. 


You can use a video camera, a portable device, external sources, and subsequently put them together in the Panopto online video editor
_items.title: Video

_items.body: Click on the option that best describes how you will record your Video.
_items.title: Step 1: Recording your video

_items.itemTitle: I am using a mobile device to record my video
I am using a computer to record my video

_items.body: Select the option that best describes how you are uploading your video.
_items.title: Step 2: Uploading your video to Panopto

_items.itemTitle: I have the video on my phone or tablet. I need to upload it to my Panopto folder
The video is on my computer, but I didn't record it with the Panopto app.

_items.body: This is the last step of the submission, and if you come so far, you want to make sure that you get this right. It's not complicated, but it's easy to miss a step, so follow the instructions scrupulously.
_items.title: Step 3: Submit the video to a Blackboard assignment

_items.itemTitle: I am using a personal computer to submit.
I am using my phone or tablet to submit.
Install Panopto on a mobile device
Install Panopto on a computer

body: Do you know what the video platform is called?
displayTitle: Are you familiar with the Video Platform used in the Ulster University?

_feedback.correct:
That's right, Panopto is the official video platform for video assignment, Recorded lesson, lecture capture and all the other video needs of staff and students at the University of Ulster. 


It was designed from the ground up to meet the needs of universities and is used across the world.

_items.text: Youtube
Vimeo
Panopto
Sharestream

title: Video platform awareness

instruction: Click on the question card to reveal the answer.

_items.backText: Your videos are stored on the cloud. This is a safe place for them and once a video has been uploaded it won't be lost.

_items.frontText: Do I need to create an account?
_items.backText: As a University of Ulster student, you already have an account and you can access it with your UU account and password.

The short answer is no. By default, when you upload a video you are the only one who can see it unless you share this video with others. When you submit a video, only you and your lecturer have access to the video.

_items.frontText: Isn't it going to get messy and difficult to find my videos?
_items.backText: Videos are stored in personal and course areas so finding videos should remain easy. You will have access to videos your lecturers have uploaded to the course area and your own personal area.

title: some facts

body:
In order to create the video you intend to submit, you will need to record it and possibly edit it. 


On this page, you will find information to help you plan and achieve the best possible video results using your smartphone.
title: Text and Graphic Title

backText:
noun


the sequence of industrial, administrative, or other processes through which a piece of work passes from initiation to completion.
title: Workflow

body: A typical workflow would look like this:

_items.title: Select your location
_items.body: Lighting and background noise are very important because they cannot be fixed once the video is recorded.
Before you commit to recording video, test your video for image and sound.
_items.title: Perform a test recording

_items.body: Now that you are satisfied with the quality of the image and sound, it's time to record your content.
_items.title: Record your video
Upload your video to Panopto
_items.body: This is a necessary step before submitting. Uploading your video can take a long time depending on its length and the settings you have used when recording the video. Therefore you should make sure you are logged in to a good wifi network.

If you have recorded the video yourself using a mobile device, it's likely that there is unwanted footage at the start and end of the video. You can edit the footage using the video editor in Panopto, as well as adding PowerPoint slides and more.
_items.title: Edit your video in Panopto

_items.body: This is the last and final step. Once your video is published on Panopto you can submit it for marking.
_items.title: Submit your video to the relevant Blackboard Learn assignment.

title: Flow Chart Title

body: Follow these guidelines to get the best results out of your recording:

_items.body:
Modern mobile devices have amazing video capabilities. They can record at amazing resolutions and framerates resulting in stunning video quality. 


The problem is that the higher the video quality, the larger the video file is going to be.


This is important if you are recording videos of more than a minute long. A high-quality video of more than a minute can take a very long time to upload and can eat your data allocation very quickly.


You should always lower the video resolution before you start recording (and use wifi to upload your video).
_items.title: Video settings

_items.body:
Set your device horizontally.


If you can, use a flat surface to set the device for a steady image. Even better, use a stand. They can easily be devised to suit your needs.
_items.title: Record in Landscape

_items.body:
Now that you're recording in the proper orientation (see 'Record in Landscape' above), completely fill the frame with your subject. You can also put your subject slightly off-center to create a more visually interesting scene. If you’re too far away, the other objects in the room will distract from the subject of the video.

Also, being closer to the subject will move the device’s microphone closer and improve the audio quality.  In general, you should always get as close as you can, especially for tight shots on faces.
_items.title: Fill the frame
Stay away from the digital zoom
_items.body: Avoid the urge to use the device’s built-in zoom feature to get closer to your subject. Most smartphones, unfortunately, feature digital zooms, which are just software tricks that'll make your subject appear closer but with severe pixelation. In order to zoom in while recording without losing the crisp quality you want in videos, you'll have to get closer to your subject.

Most mobile phones and tablets have the microphone at the bottom edge of the device near the charging port.

For the best audio quality, try not to cover the microphone with your hand when holding the device in landscape mode. Avoid tapping the microphone, or moving your hands too much while recording….as this will be picked up.
_items.title: Don't cover the microphone

_items.body:
While you may be able to see people and their faces when they're backlit e.g. with a projector screen behind them, your mobile devices’ camera usually can't and will output footage with a bright light haloing a dark figure. The subject will have no visible features and will appear in silhouette.


To avoid this situation, try considering the lighting and positioning of your subject. Get as much natural – window - light as possible and consider standing your subject beside – but not in front of - a window or projector screen. Those of you who are recording on the fly can also improve a backlit situation by moving to one side or another. Some smartphones video apps do try to reduce the effects of backlighting; however, you can reduce the problem with a good choice of location. Alternatively, use a fill-in light to brighten your subject.
_items.title: Backlighting is bad

_items.body: On the subject of location for recording, choose a quiet room, away from distractions and the general flow of other people in the corridors outside. Old, wood-floored or high ceiling rooms should be avoided because of problems with echo affecting audio quality. Carpeted rooms are ideal, as are those with shelves lined with books etc. as these tend to cut down on echo and external distractions.
_items.title: Location

title: Recording guidelines

body:
This is the most obvious app to use to record your video.


When using your camera app, be mindful of the video settings. Modern phones record at very high resolution for the nicest looking video. This results in very large video files, meaning that uploading your video can take a very long time.
title: Phone camera

_feedback.correct: Excellent, you should be ready to record and get the best quality out of your video.

_incorrect.notFinal: You can still improve the quality of your recording by carefully managing the lighting and sound during the recording of your video.
_incorrect.final: You can still improve the quality of your recording by carefully managing the lighting and sound during the recording of your video.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Good, but you can still improve the quality of your recording by carefully managing the lighting and sound during the recording of your video.
_partlyCorrect.final: Good, but you can still improve the quality of your recording by carefully managing the lighting and sound during the recording of your video.

_items.text: Do a test recording to check the image and sound quality of the recording.
Make sure you are a quiet environment.
Make sure I have good wifi
Check that the main source of light in the room is not behind me.

body: What should you do before you start recording your video?
title: GMCQ Title

_feedback.correct: Excellent! You are ready to record the best possible video.

_incorrect.notFinal: You can still improve the quality of your video by going over some of the content on this page!

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: You can still improve the quality of your video! Keep in mind that the sound quality is the most important.
_partlyCorrect.final: You can still improve the quality of your video! Keep in mind that the sound quality is the most important.

_options.text: Record with the device in landscape orientation
Change the orientation when I edit the video in Panopto

I can change the video orientation when I upload it to Panopto

_options.text: Make sure to record in a quiet room, with no fans or buzzing noises, music or other people talking.
Use an app to clean up the sound.

_items.text: The voice isn't clear and some words are difficult to make out.

_options.text: Check that the main light source is not behind you

_items.text: The video is not clear

Check that the microphone is not obstructed, speak clearly and loudly as if you were talking to several people in a room.

The room you are recording in is too dark.

displayTitle: Match the issues with the cause
body: There are a number of issues you can easily avoid to ensure your video meets the minimum quality requirements.
instruction: Match the problem with the solution
title: Matching factors

body:
Once you have your video, you need to upload to Panopto so you can further edit it should you need to, and so you can submit the video to Blackboard Learn.


Choose where you want to go from here or use the home button at the bottom of the page.

_items.itemTitle: Upload your video to your Panopto account
Submit your video
Edit your video in Panopto
Install the Panopto App

title: What's next?

body:
If you choose to edit your video on your phone, there are many options. Some apps offer you the ability to edit different clips together, add transitions, titles and more. 


Depending on your device type and operating system (iOS or Android), there are a few different choices when it comes to recording and editing your video.
title: Apps

displayTitle: Editing your video on your mobile device
body: Here is a short list of recommended Apps you can use to edit your video on your device.

_items.body:
Available on iOS and Android.

  • Free
  • Capture and editing

Export your edited video using the Share to Gallery function, then upload using the Panopto app.

Download the app and learn how to use it at this link: Adobe Premiere Rush.
_items.title: Adobe Premiere Rush

_items.body:
KineMaster is a fully featured video editor. KineMaster is best used on more powerful devices, and larger screens are recommended in order to take full advantages of its features.


  • 7-day free trial, subscription thereafter.
  • Android and iOS
  • Fully featured editor
  • Multiple layers and transitions
  • Multitrack audio 


KineMaster download links and help files at the following link: KineMaster
_items.title: KineMaster
iMovie
_items.body:
iMovie is Apple's entry video editor and is available on iOS and OSX. 


  • Free for iPhone and Mac users
  • Easy to use and fully featured


iMovie is available on the iTunes store.

title: Video apps

displayTitle: What do I need to record a video on a computer?

_items.text:
In order to capture image and sound for your video, you will need a webcam. Laptops generally have an integrated webcam and microphone.


Even if you don't intend to record the image from your camera, using an external webcam is still recommended as it performs as a microphone as well.


Click on the links for more detail on using the Panopto app and the Panopto Video Editor.

We recommend that you use the Pantopto app to record your video.


The Panopto app allows you to perform a simple recording, or record several sources at once such as your camera, your desktop, a powerpoint presentation and more.


Once recorded, the video goes straight to your Panopto folder on the cloud.

title: What do I need?

title: Video walkthrough

body: The easiest way to upload your video to your Panopto account prior to submission is to use the web browser on your phone.
title: Text Title

_items.title: Login to Blackboard with your browser
_items.body:
Go to:


learning.ulster.ac.uk



Enter your student number and password
This will open your Panopto account in a new window.
_items.title: Click the link

_items.body:
Your Panopto account is displayed in a new window. 


Select Create in the top menu.
_items.title: Select Create
Select the video file to upload
_items.body:
Select your video by tapping Choose video or audio files (2)


You can also select the destination for your video. Unless you want to put your video in a shared folder, leave the destination as My Folder. (1)

_items.title: File upload progress
_items.body:
Video files can get very large. Make sure that you are logged in to a fast wifi connection before starting the upload or it may severely impact on your data allowance.


Even on a fast wifi connection, uploading a video will take a significant amount of time.

body: Now that your video is sitting on your Panopto account, you can either:

_items.itemTitle: Submit your video
Edit your video before submitting it

title: Link Title

_items.body: The video I want to submit is on my computer. What should I do now?

Before submitting your file, you need to upload it to your Panopto account. 

Follow the steps below to do that.

_items.title: On a computer, you can access your account through the Panopto app if you have it installed and have used it before.
It's usually better to access your Panopto account through Blackboard by clicking on the link given to you in the assignment you are working on.

Uploading your Video to Panopto does not mean it's submitted. 
There are a few more steps to do to complete the submission.
Once you have uploaded your video, follow the instructions here to complete your submission.

displayTitle: Uploading a video to your Panopto account using a computer

_items.body: Find the assignment on Blackboard, then click the link in Step 1. This will open your Panopto Account Page in a new window or tab in the browser.
_items.title: Start from your Blackboard assignment

_items.body: Click the Create menu and select Upload Media.
_items.title: From your Panopto Account page:
Find the file you want to upload
_items.body:
Click on Choose video or audio files, then navigate to and select the file you want to upload.


You can also choose where to put your file, but unless you have lots of videos and you want to create folders to keep them organised you will use the default setting.

title: Uploading a video to Panopto

title: Link Title

displayTitle: There are two ways you can upload your video:

_items.itemTitle: Upload using a normal web browser (easiest)
Use the app (keep reading this page)

title: Link Title

displayTitle: Check that you have taken the following steps before attempting to upload a video to your Panopto section.

_items.title: The Panopto app is installed on your device.
You have logged in to your Panopto account.

title: Pre-requisite steps to uploading a video

_items.title: Sign in
_items.body:
Sign in to Panopto (you already be logged in, if so skip to the next step).


Make sure you select Ulster Blackboard from the drop-down menu

_items.title: Tap the Choose video or audio file then navigate to the file you want to upload.
Upload your file
_items.body:
As soon as you have selected the file, the upload will start.



Video files can get very large in size. Make sure you are connected to the internet with a fast and reliable wifi connection.

Once uploaded, your file will be processed. The processing time will vary depending on the size of the file.


Once the processing is finished, your file will be available to view, edit or submit. 


Please note: at this point, your assignment is NOT submitted.
_items.title: Processing.....

displayTitle: Now that your video is uploaded to your Panopto account, you can:

_items.itemTitle: Click here for instructions on how to submit the video you have just uploaded
Use the Online Video Editor to top and tail your video, add more content such as PowerPoint slides, other videos and more.

_items.body: This is what the assignment looks like.
_items.title: Navigate to your assignment
Open the Assignment dropbox
_items.body: Click on the assignment title to open the dropbox.

_items.title: Assignment submission page
_items.body:
This is what the assignment submission page looks like. 




Click Write Submission
Click the Mashups menu and select Panopto Student Video Submission.
_items.title: Click the Mashups menu
Select your video
_items.body: Select your video, then click Submit Video.

_items.title: Ready to submit
_items.body:
The link to your video is now embedded in the submission text ('sample' in this example).


You can add text or attach files as required, but do not remove or edit the link.
Click the Submit button to finish the submission process.
_items.title: Submit your assignment

_source: <iframe src="https://ulster.cloud.panopto.eu/Panopto/Pages/Viewer.aspx?id=26a01502-a90a-4a38-8352-a974012425aa&start=9.44647" width="720" height="405" style="padding: 0px; border: 1px solid #464646;" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen allow="autoplay"></iframe>
title: iFrame Title

displayTitle: Do not attempt to submit with the Blackboard App
body:
Students using a mobile device can submit a Panopto Student Video Assignment by logging into Blackboard Learn using the browser on their mobile device. 


However, the Blackboard App DOES NOT support the Panopto student assignment tool. While the Panopto assignment link can be opened by the Blackboard App, it should not be used to submit a Panopto Assignment.


Also Note: Mobile users should connect to a WiFi source when submitting, as uploading a video file via your mobile network will incur significant data costs.
title: Text Title

displayTitle: Submitting using a browser on of mobile device.

_items.body: To submitting a video to a Blackboard assignment using a browser on a mobile device, follow the same steps you would on a computer.
_items.itemTitle: Submitting using a browser on a mobile device.

title: link to computer submission

displayTitle: Accessing your account for the first time
body:
When you install the app and try to log in you may get an error message if you haven't accessed your account before using the app. 


If you encounter this error, go to Blackboard and either 

  • find and click the Panopto item in the menu
  • navigate to the Assignment dropbox and click on the link in Step 1 of the instructions.
title: Accessing your account for the first time

instruction: Click on the image to reveal the instructions

_items.text:
You can install the Panopto app for iOS from the Apple App Store. Use the version that is relevant to your device. 


Note that you will need to login before using the app.
_items.title: iOS device installation
Android device installation
_items.text: On an Android device, simply search then install the Panopto app from the Play Store.

title: Mobile device

body: Now that the app is installed, you need to log in.

_items.itemTitle: Log in with the Android app.
Log in with the iOS app.

title: Links to logging in

displayTitle: Logging in with the Android App
body:
Follow these steps to log in using the Android App. 


Be aware that you need to have accessed your Panopto account through Blackboard first.

_items.title: Sign-in process
_items.body: After entering your Ulster University email address when prompted, Click on the dropdown menu

_items.title: Blackboard sign-in
_items.body: Click Agree and Continue and enter your student number and password.

_items.title: You're in
_items.body: You should see the videos available for you to watch, and you should have an upload icon to upload videos to your account.

title: Android App

displayTitle: Logging in with the iOS app
body:
Follow these steps to log in using the iOS App. 


Be aware that you need to have accessed your Panopto account through Blackboard first.

_items.body: Open the App and click Sign In

In the Sign In dialogue window, change from Sign in using Panopto

to Ulster Blackboard.

Once you have selected Ulster Blackboard, hit Sign in.  


Enter your Student Number (B number) and password.
Select Agree and Continue
Enter your student number (starting with b) and password.
Once you are signed in, choose Record and Upload you will see the folders currently present in your account. Select one of the folders.

title: iOS app login

displayTitle: Accessing your account for the first time
body:
When you install the app and try to log in you may get an error message if you haven't accessed your account before using the app. 


If you encounter this error, go to Blackboard and either 

  • find and click the Panopto item in the menu
  • navigate to the Assignment dropbox and click on the link in Step 1 of the instructions.
title: First time

displayTitle: You can install the free Panopto app by following these steps:

_items.body: Log in to Blackboard and navigate to the Video Assessment and click the link shown below:

This will open a new browser page (make sure pop-ups are enabled in your browser preferences).

Click Download Panopto
Download the version corresponding to your operating system.
The Panopto installer will begin downloading.
Once the download is is over, double-click on the installer file to begin the installation process.
Go with the default options and select the next/continue buttons until the installation completes.
Once the installation has completed, restart your computer.

title: Flow Chart Title

body: To sign in with the Panopto app, click the Sign In and select Ulster Blackboard from the dropdown menu.
title: Text Title

A "covered work" means either the unmodified Program or a work based

To "propagate" a work means to do anything with it that, without

infringement under applicable copyright law, except executing it on a

distribution (with or without modification), making available to the
public, and in some countries other activities as well.

To "convey" a work means any kind of propagation that enables other
parties to make or receive copies. Mere interaction with a user through
a computer network, with no transfer of a copy, is not conveying.

An interactive user interface displays "Appropriate Legal Notices"
to the extent that it includes a convenient and prominently visible

the interface presents a list of user commands or options, such as a
menu, a prominent item in the list meets this criterion.

1. Source Code.

The "source code" for a work means the preferred form of the work
for making modifications to it. "Object code" means any non-source
form of a work.

A "Standard Interface" means an interface that either is an official
standard defined by a recognized standards body, or, in the case of
interfaces specified for a particular programming language, one that
is widely used among developers working in that language.

The "System Libraries" of an executable work include anything, other
than the work as a whole, that (a) is included in the normal form of
packaging a Major Component, but which is not part of that Major
Component, and (b) serves only to enable use of the work with that
Major Component, or to implement a Standard Interface for which an
implementation is available to the public in source code form. A
"Major Component", in this context, means a major essential component
(kernel, window system, and so on) of the specific operating system
(if any) on which the executable work runs, or a compiler used to
produce the work, or an object code interpreter used to run it.

The "Corresponding Source" for a work in object code form means all
the source code needed to generate, install, and (for an executable

control those activities. However, it does not include the work's

which are not part of the work. For example, Corresponding Source
includes interface definition files associated with source files for

linked subprograms that the work is specifically designed to require,
such as by intimate data communication or control flow between those

The Corresponding Source need not include anything that users
can regenerate automatically from other parts of the Corresponding
Source.

The Corresponding Source for a work in source code form is that

A separable portion of the object code, whose source code is excluded

A "User Product" is either (1) a "consumer product", which means any

or household purposes, or (2) anything designed or sold for incorporation

actually uses, or expects or is expected to use, the product. A product
is a consumer product regardless of whether the product has substantial
commercial, industrial or non-consumer uses, unless such uses represent
the only significant mode of use of the product.

"Installation Information" for a User Product means any methods,
procedures, authorization keys, or other information required to install
and execute modified versions of a covered work in that User Product from
a modified version of its Corresponding Source. The information must

If you convey an object code work under this section in, or with, or
specifically for use in, a User Product, and the conveying occurs as

Corresponding Source conveyed under this section must be accompanied

modified object code on the User Product (for example, the work has

The requirement to provide Installation Information does not include a

the User Product in which it has been modified or installed. Access to a

Corresponding Source conveyed, and Installation Information provided,
in accord with this section must be in a format that is publicly
documented (and with an implementation available to the public in
source code form), and must require no special password or key for
unpacking, reading or copying.

If you develop a new program, and you want it to be of the greatest

To do so, attach the following notices to the program. It is safest
to attach them to the start of each source file to most effectively
state the exclusion of warranty; and each file should have at least
the "copyright" line and a pointer to where the full notice is found.

<one line to give the program's name and a brief idea of what it does.>
Copyright (C) <year> <name of author>

This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify
it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by

(at your option) any later version.

You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
along with this program. If not, see <https://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.

Also add information on how to contact you by electronic and paper mail.

If the program does terminal interaction, make it output a short
notice like this when it starts in an interactive mode:

<program> Copyright (C) <year> <name of author>
This program comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY; for details type `show w'.
This is free software, and you are welcome to redistribute it
under certain conditions; type `show c' for details.

The hypothetical commands `show w' and `show c' should show the appropriate
parts of the General Public License. Of course, your program's commands
might be different; for a GUI interface, you would use an "about box".

You should also get your employer (if you work as a programmer) or school,
if any, to sign a "copyright disclaimer" for the program, if necessary.
For more information on this, and how to apply and follow the GNU GPL, see
<https://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.
